reinforcements.similarity: Both address pricing transparency through visual hierarchy and clear total-cost display. The existing element prescribes showing 'One Total Before Any Breakdown' for hosts. The new element prescribes showing total lease cost prominently for guests with per-bedroom clarification.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: Andreas processes 'first month... broker's fee? One month. Three months' as a single sum. New: Tapper experiences 2x cost surprise when per-bedroom pricing isn't clarified upfront. Both use large, dominant typography for total cost. Combined insight: total-first pricing display is a cross-role pattern that prevents dropout (host) and restores trust (guest). The per-bedroom clarification is guest-specific but the hierarchy principle applies to both journeys.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge—extend Single-Sum Financial Display to cover guest-facing pricing with per-bedroom clarification as a guest-specific variant

reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust-building through transparency. Existing element focuses on bridging Bryant's trust to the platform via continuity priming (agent name, photo, call references). New element focuses on pricing transparency as trust foundation for the guest journey.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: Trust is built with Bryant (person), not Split Lease (platform). Host encounters platform as unprimed stimulus. New: Tapper's pricing confusion creates distrust that carries forward, reducing review participation. Both cite Kahneman on priming and associative coherence. Combined insight: trust must be established early or the entire relationship suffers. Host-side trust comes from human continuity; guest-side trust comes from pricing transparency. Both are System 1 trust gates.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both—different trust mechanisms for different roles, but both reinforce the principle that early trust shapes all subsequent engagement

reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition)
reinforcements.similarity: EXACT MATCH. The new element from the Tapper run is addressing the same review-trigger transition problem as the existing library element, but for guests instead of hosts. Both use System 1 approval as the theoretical foundation.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: Each phase transition triggers System 1 assessment; must pass automatic check before System 2 engages. New: Cleaning photo → review card transition must feel like natural continuation, not interruption. Both cite Kahneman's associative coherence. Combined: System 1 continuity applies to micro-transitions (cleaning photos → review) and macro-transitions (evaluation → onboarding).
reinforcements.recommendation: merge—the existing element covers phase transitions broadly; extend it with the cleaning-photo-to-review example as a micro-transition case study

reinforcements.similarity: STRONG OVERLAP. New element prescribes progressive review simplification via long loops. Existing element prescribes smart defaults and save-and-resume for depleted users in multi-step processes. Both cite Kahneman's ego depletion research.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: After exerting self-control in one task, people default to denial (parole judge study). New: By stay 5-6, guests experience review fatigue and stop participating. Both solutions use pre-population and defaults to reduce effort. Combined: Long loops (progressive simplification) are the temporal dimension of designing for depletion.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge—extend Design for the Depleted User with long loops as a specific pattern for reducing depletion in repeated interactions

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe optimistic UI with instant feedback. New element: star tap → instant fill → spring animation. Existing patterns likely cover similar interaction design principles.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: New: Star tap must respond in <50ms to feel instant, using spring easing. Sub-100ms creates perception of instantaneousness. This is likely reinforcing existing library patterns around optimistic UI and immediate feedback.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both—pending review of existing behaves elements to confirm overlap; if library already has optimistic UI patterns, merge; if not, this is an extension

reinforcements.similarity: Both address progressive disclosure and prioritization of form fields. New element prescribes REQUIRED/STRONGLY RECOMMENDED/OPTIONAL tiers for guest proposal creation. This pattern likely exists for hosts in listing creation.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: New: Tapper told to 'complete profile, upload photo, write traveler story' with no priority guidance. Solution: tiered fields with completion percentage. This mirrors profile completion patterns that likely exist in the host journey.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge—if library has host profile completion patterns, extend to cover guest proposal creation as symmetric pattern

reinforcements.similarity: Both address data transparency to create empowerment and reduce anxiety. New element: show acceptance likelihood + optimization tips during bid creation. This likely reinforces existing patterns around data-driven guidance.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: New: Robert reveals 'Sunday night is hard to book'—platform knowledge that should be surfaced. Guest empowerment via real-time acceptance likelihood. This is a cross-role pattern: both hosts and guests need data transparency to make informed decisions.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both—if library has host-side data transparency, this is the guest-side equivalent; together they form a complete picture of mutual empowerment

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease phase review mechanics. Existing library has WEAK coverage of active_lease (per run instructions). This element fills the 'how do reviews get triggered' gap with contextual system triggers tied to cleaning photos.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence with one lens (Tapper call + Microinteractions book). The cleaning photo trigger is a strong insight, but would benefit from additional guest calls to validate that cleaning photos are a consistent high-engagement moment.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease phase review volume generation. Library likely lacks stay-by-stay review patterns. This element introduces 'Same as last time' one-tap option and pre-population patterns specific to long-term recurring relationships.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Long loops are well-documented in Microinteractions book. The application to stay-by-stay reviews is novel and addresses the 12+ reviews per lease volume challenge.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease phase behavioral triggers. When host reviews guest, guest receives reciprocity-trigger notification. This secondary trigger pattern is new territory.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. Reciprocity is a proven behavioral principle, but this specific implementation (host reviews guest → guest prompted) needs validation with additional guest calls to confirm effectiveness.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease review form information architecture. Pre-populating review forms with stay metadata (dates, room, nights) to reduce blank-page syndrome. Applies 'Don't Start from Zero' principle to reviews.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. This is a direct application of Microinteractions principles to a specific use case. Low risk.

extensions.gap_filled: acceptance phase expectations management. Using lease signing moment to establish stay-by-stay reviews as expected norm. Prevents surprise and resistance later.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Norm-setting at acceptance is sound practice, but the specific copy and framing would benefit from A/B testing to optimize guest receptivity.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease review form structure. 2-3 questions max (star rating + optional comment + optional issue flag) to maintain high completion rates across 12+ stays.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. 'Less Is More' is core Microinteractions principle. The 2-3 question limit is well-justified by the book and the guest journey context.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease review form information architecture. Complements works-006 by defining HOW 2-3 fields should be structured and prioritized visually.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Directly supports works-006. The hierarchy (PRIMARY: star rating, SECONDARY: comment, TERTIARY: issue flag) is clear and justified.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease review notification structure. Embedding stay metadata IN the notification (not just the form) to reduce memory burden.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. 'Bring the Data Forward' from Microinteractions book. Low implementation risk.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease review form interaction. Pre-populating ratings from prior stays to transform from generation task to recognition task. Core to long loops.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Directly cited in Microinteractions book as volume multiplier.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease feedback loop. Guest-facing dashboard showing their review contributions and impact metrics. No existing library element covers this.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The concept is sound (visible impact increases motivation), but the specific metrics and layout would benefit from additional validation.

extensions.gap_filled: acceptance phase communication. Content structure for 'How Reviews Work' in lease confirmation email. Complements works-005.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Framing matters (optional favor vs expected norm), but specific copy needs testing.

extensions.gap_filled: negotiation phase information architecture. Real-time acceptance likelihood + optimization tips during bid creation. New territory for guest journey.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. Tapper call provides strong evidence (Robert's coaching), but platform data quality (can we accurately calculate acceptance likelihood?) is uncertain.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease visual design. Lightweight card design (soft colors, generous spacing, minimal fields) to signal 'quick task.' Supports works-006.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Visual weight = cognitive weight is well-established design principle.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease visual design. Custom star styling with spring animation OR emoji scale alternative. Adds personality to review interaction.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Spring animation is low-risk. Emoji scale is higher-risk (might feel too casual for some guests) and would benefit from testing.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease visual feedback. Small progress indicator ('Stay 3 of 12') to combat review fatigue by showing progress. Supports long loops.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Progress indicators reduce perceived burden (end is in sight). Low implementation risk.

extensions.new_element_id: looks-004 (Cleaning Photo → Review Transition Visual Continuity)
extensions.gap_filled: active_lease visual transition. Slide-up overlay with cleaning photo thumbnail to maintain visual continuity. Supports works-001.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Visual continuity reduces context-switching friction. Slide-up modal is familiar pattern.

extensions.gap_filled: search and listing_evaluation visual design. Dramatic typographic scale (36px total cost vs 18px breakdown vs 12px details) to prevent pricing confusion. Addresses Tapper's core pain point.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Tapper's pricing confusion is severe (2x cost surprise). Visual hierarchy is proven solution. Reinforces existing library element on Single-Sum Financial Display.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease visual design. 60% opacity for pre-populated stars, 'Same as last time' label, large confirm button. Makes pre-population visible. Supports communicates-003.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Pre-population must be visible or cognitive benefit is lost. Clear visual differentiation achieves this.

extensions.new_element_id: looks-007 (Review Prompt Contextual Metadata Visual Layout)
extensions.gap_filled: active_lease visual layout. Horizontal layout for metadata header (thumbnail + property name + dates). Supports communicates-002.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Metadata-at-top is standard pattern. Thumbnail provides visual anchor. Low risk.

extensions.new_element_id: looks-008 (Acceptance Phase Review Norm Visual Framing)
extensions.gap_filled: acceptance visual design. Light purple callout box in lease confirmation email with 'How Reviews Work' content. Supports communicates-007.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Callout box creates visual distinction without being aggressive. Branded color (purple) signals importance.

extensions.new_element_id: behaves-002 ('Same as Last Time' One-Tap Confirmation)
extensions.gap_filled: active_lease interaction. One-tap button interaction with loading → success → dismiss sequence. Core to long loops volume multiplier.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. One-tap submission is the behavioral manifestation of progressive simplification. Well-supported by Microinteractions book.

extensions.new_element_id: behaves-003 (Cleaning Photo → Review Card Slide-Up Transition)
extensions.gap_filled: active_lease interaction. 500ms delay, slide-up modal, dismissal gestures, snooze options. Supports works-001.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Timing (500ms) prevents premature trigger. Slide-up is familiar mobile pattern. Snooze gives guest control.

extensions.new_element_id: behaves-004 (Review Prompt System Trigger Timing Logic)
extensions.gap_filled: active_lease system logic. Tiered trigger system: primary (cleaning photos), fallback 1 (4hr push), fallback 2 (24hr app open), fallback 3 (48hr banner). Multi-tiered approach is new.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Tiered logic is sound (try high-engagement first, fall back if needed), but specific timings (4hr, 24hr, 48hr) are estimates that should be tuned based on data.

extensions.gap_filled: proposal_creation interaction. Optimistic bid submission (instant checkmark, background sync). Reduces proposal submission anxiety.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Optimistic UI is well-established pattern. Tapper's hesitation ('should I click the bid option?') justifies instant confirmation.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease interaction. Multi-level snooze options (1 hour, Tonight, Tomorrow) with adaptive learning (system learns guest's preferred timing). Supports behaves-003.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Snooze options give guest control (reduces annoyance). Adaptive learning is sophisticated but requires data to tune. Start simple (fixed options), add learning later.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease emotional experience. Post-review confirmation emphasizing mutual benefit and visible impact ('Your review helps 50+ guests'). Transforms transactional into communal.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Reciprocity requires visible impact. The copy shift from 'Thank you' to 'You're helping 50+ guests' is well-justified.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease emotional arc. Reviews must feel progressively LIGHTER (obligation → habit → automatic) via long loops. Prevents review fatigue.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Emotional weight must decrease with repetition. Progressive simplification creates positive emotional momentum. Well-supported.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease emotional feedback. Guests need to see their voice is being heard ('50+ guests viewed your review this week'). Combats void anxiety.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. 'Shouting into void' kills motivation. Visible view counts and engagement metrics create confidence.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease emotional tone. Reviews should preserve warmth of host-guest relationship via conversational prompts, host photo, relationship history. Prevents bureaucratic feel.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Tapper's warm interaction with Robert contrasts with cold form-filling. Host photo and name humanize the review. Low risk.

extensions.gap_filled: acceptance emotional experience. Using acceptance phase to calmly set expectations for stay-by-stay reviews prevents surprise/resentment later. Supports works-005.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Expectation-setting is sound practice. Acceptance timing (positive emotional state) is strategic. Specific copy needs validation.

extensions.gap_filled: active_lease emotional reception. Review prompts tied to existing flows (cleaning photos, next-stay notifications) feel like natural next steps, not interruptions. Reduces annoyance.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Context-appropriate timing increases receptivity. Random push notifications create resentment. Well-supported by Microinteractions book and Tapper journey analysis.

token_compliance.recommendation: All visual tokens reference existing design system (tokens.json). No new tokens introduced that conflict with existing system. The run uses tokens.json (warm beige palette) not style-guide.md (purple palette), which is correct per the project context.

journey_emotion_map.arc_note: Guest is learning platform mechanics. Transparency about pricing structure (per-bedroom, total cost) prevents early distrust. Elements: feels-005 (Pricing Transparency Trust Foundation).
Guest needs efficient filtering. Pricing clarity and budget comparison reduce friction. Elements: communicates-004 (Pricing Transparency Hierarchy).
Pricing confusion peaks here. Visual hierarchy (36px total cost) and per-bedroom clarification prevent dropout. Elements: looks-005 (Pricing Clarity), feels-005 (Trust Foundation).

Guest ready to bid but uncertain about what increases acceptance odds. Data transparency creates empowerment. Elements: feels-006 (Negotiation Empowerment), communicates-008 (Guidance Data Transparency), behaves-005 (Optimistic Bid Confirmation).
Guest learning which variables are negotiable. Real-time acceptance likelihood reduces anxiety. Elements: feels-006 (Empowerment), communicates-008 (Data Transparency).

Positive emotional state makes this ideal moment to set review expectations. Elements: works-005 (Review Norm Setting), communicates-007 (Norm Framing), looks-008 (Visual Framing), feels-007 (Expectation-Setting Calm).

First reality check. House Manual and proactive check-ins reduce issues. This run doesn't deeply address move_in (consistent with weak library coverage), but sets foundation via acceptance-phase expectations.

THE review phase. Every element must support high volume (12+ reviews). Emotional arc: obligation → habit → automatic. Key elements: feels-001 (Gratitude), feels-002 (Lightness), feels-003 (Voice Amplification), feels-004 (Human Continuity), feels-008 (Non-Interruption). All works/communicates/looks/behaves elements for active_lease support this arc.

emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc makes sense and is well-supported by the elements. Discovery and listing_evaluation focus on building trust through pricing transparency. Acceptance establishes expectations in a positive emotional state. Active_lease maintains high volume through progressive lightness (long loops) and continuous positive reinforcement (gratitude, voice amplification). No jarring emotional shifts. The arc flows from uncertain → secure → prepared → effortless → appreciated.

discovery.note: feels-005 (Pricing Transparency Trust Foundation) addresses discovery-phase distrust caused by pricing confusion. Additional discovery elements may exist in library (trust gates, platform education).

search.note: communicates-004 (Pricing Transparency Hierarchy) addresses search-phase filtering and budget comparison. Tapper call doesn't deeply explore search phase, so thin coverage is appropriate.

listing_evaluation.note: Pricing confusion is the central pain point here. Elements: communicates-004 (Pricing Hierarchy), looks-005 (Pricing Clarity), feels-005 (Trust Foundation). All address the per-bedroom pricing surprise and calculation burden.

proposal_creation.note: Elements: communicates-005 (Profile Completeness), communicates-008 (Negotiation Guidance), behaves-005 (Optimistic Bid Confirmation), feels-006 (Empowerment). Cover profile completion friction, bid optimization, and submission confidence.

negotiation.note: Elements: communicates-008 (Negotiation Guidance), feels-006 (Empowerment). Both address data transparency to improve bid acceptance. Tapper call touches on negotiation (night flexibility) but doesn't deeply explore counter-offer flows.

acceptance.note: Elements: works-005 (Review Norm Setting), communicates-007 (Norm Framing), looks-008 (Visual Framing), feels-007 (Expectation-Setting Calm). All focus on establishing stay-by-stay review expectations at lease signing. This is strategic—acceptance is the ideal norm-setting moment.

move_in.note: Tapper call doesn't address move_in phase. The run instructions note library has weak coverage here. This run focuses on active_lease (reviews), so move_in gap remains. Future runs should address move_in microinteractions (House Manual, first-stay check-ins).

active_lease.note: THE focus of this run. 30 elements across all layers (works: 6, communicates: 8, looks: 8, behaves: 6, feels: 5 if excluding cross-phase). Covers review triggers (cleaning photos), form design (2-3 questions), long loops (Same as last time), visual design (lightweight cards, progress), interactions (one-tap, snooze), emotions (gratitude, lightness, voice amplification). This is the most comprehensive coverage of any single phase in the library. Active_lease review system is now fully specified.

loop_back_recommendations.gap: No elements from this run address move_in. Library has weak coverage here (per instructions). Future guest runs should explore: (1) House Manual microinteractions (how to make rules scannable and memorable), (2) First-stay check-ins (proactive issue detection before they become review complaints), (3) Reality vs listing expectations (visual continuity between listing photos and first arrival).
loop_back_recommendations.rationale: Move_in is the first moment where review sentiment is formed. If the space matches or exceeds expectations, guests are primed for positive reviews. Gaps here create downstream review risk.

loop_back_recommendations.gap: This run covers review microinteractions comprehensively but doesn't address the other stay lifecycle components: arrival notifications, active stay touchpoints, cleaning photo submission (host-side). Future runs should explore: (1) What makes a good arrival notification? (2) How should guests interact with the platform during active stays? (3) How does cleaning photo submission work for hosts, and does it create friction?
loop_back_recommendations.rationale: The review system depends on cleaning photos as triggers, but we haven't deeply examined the cleaning photo submission flow itself. If hosts don't submit photos reliably, the primary review trigger fails.

loop_back_recommendations.gap: Tapper call reveals search friction (Robert manually filters because platform doesn't) but this run focuses on pricing, not search mechanics. Future runs should explore: (1) Pet-friendly filtering (hidden constraint that should surface early), (2) Night selection and calendar interface, (3) Budget-based filtering and recommendations.
loop_back_recommendations.rationale: Tapper mentions Robert has to manually filter listings because there are 'too many to remember.' This reveals a search/filtering gap that affects discovery-to-evaluation conversion.

loop_back_recommendations.gap: This run establishes review norm-setting at acceptance but doesn't address the broader lease signing experience: How are lease documents delivered? What's the signing flow? What other expectations need to be set beyond reviews?
loop_back_recommendations.rationale: Acceptance phase is about more than just review expectations. The lease signing experience itself may have friction that affects trust and satisfaction.

loop_back_recommendations.gap: Tapper's negotiation is relatively smooth (adjusting nights based on Robert's coaching), but the call doesn't explore: (1) What happens when a bid is rejected? (2) How do guests construct counter-offers? (3) How does the platform communicate rejection reasons?
loop_back_recommendations.rationale: This run addresses bid optimization (acceptance likelihood) but not the rejection/counter-offer flows. These are emotionally sensitive moments that need careful design.

loop_back_recommendations.gap: This run introduces 30 new elements, many of which share common patterns (card layouts, button styles, progress indicators). Future work should consolidate these into reusable components to prevent design drift.
loop_back_recommendations.rationale: Token compliance is good (all references to existing tokens.json), but component proliferation risk is high. Review cards, confirm buttons, metadata headers should be documented as reusable components.
